name: cucumis-dipsaceus
edibility: Fruits, seeds and young leaves and shoots are all edible.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
fruit-description: Hairs cover the oblong fruit giving the species the nickname  “hedgehog cucumber”. Fruits appear in November to January. They start out green and turn yellow when mature and contain many seeds.
flower-description: Flowers are monoecious and unisexual with each plant having separate male and female flowers. The male flowers range from 1/2 to 3/4 of an inch and have three stamens. Female flowers range from 3/4 to 1 inch and have three-lobed stigmas. Blooms September to November.
leaf-description: The heart-shaped leaves are trilobed and notched at the base. The leaves grow 3/4- 3 inches long and 1-3.5 inches wide with hairs covering both sides of the leaf surfaces. The margins are toothed.
stem-description: Stems grow to 6 feet or more with a climbing habit. Quadrangular shaped with hairs and weak.
uses: Fruits are used for fodder, medicinally as an analgesic, and human consumption.
